post_text:
#WellnessWednesday - Importance of Hydration
Your body is 60% water, so it makes sense that maintaining healthy hydration keeps your body systems working like they should. Remember caffeine has reverse effects on your body’s function. By the time you feel thirsty your body is already dehydrated; our thirst mechanism lags behind our actual level of hydration. Research shows that as little as 1 percent dehydration negatively affects your mood, attention, memory and motor coordination. Therefore, make sure your child has a tall glass of water during the instructional day or is taking regular hydration breaks to keep their brain healthy and functioning at its very best!

Resource: https://www.sciencealert.com/here-s-what-happens-to-your-body-when-you-re-dehydrated

post_text:
CCISD continues to offer free curbside breakfast and lunch on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 10:30 am to 12:30 pm or until supplies last. Curbside locations include all ten middle schools and the six comprehensive high schools.

With flexibilities offered by USDA, free curbside meals are now offered to children 1 – 18 years of age who are not back at school for face to face learning. In order to comply with federal guidelines, parents with or without children present must show evidence of children in the household, such as student ID number, barcode, or birth certificate or similar identification for non-school age students. Once evidence is presented, staff will provide families with a number to display, eliminating the need to bring evidence daily.

American Foundation for Suicide Prevention
September 10 at 10:40 AM ·

Today, on #WorldSuicidePreventionDay, and every day, we're working towards a world without suicide. By learning the warning signs, you can help #StopSuicide. Warning signs can appear in a person's behavior, mood, or how they talk, and there is no single cause for suicide.

Learn more about risk factors and the warning signs of suicide at afsp.org/signs

As we continue to welcome students to campus, we will be sharing numbers of test-confirmed cases in our district. The district’s COVID-19 chart includes cases listed by campus as well as a category for non-campus properties.

You may view the chart here: https://www.ccisd.us/Covid-19-cases

When the district learns of a test-confirmed case, contact tracing helps determine which additional individuals, if any, may need to be notified. Campuses, in accordance with Texas Education Agency guidance, will also notify all staff and families if there is a test-confirmed case on that campus.

The chart will be updated each business day and is for informational purposes only.

To learn more about CCISD’s safety measures, you may review the Reopening Plan at https://www.ccisd.us/2020-reopening-plan. If you have additional questions, we encourage families to visit with their child’s school and employees to work with their supervisor. You may also send questions to ccisd.tx@k12-lets-talk.com.

post_text:
#WellnessWednesday Focused Breathing
When deep breathing is focused and slow, it can help reduce anxiety. You can do this technique by sitting or lying down in a quiet, comfortable location. Then:
1. Notice how it feels when you inhale and exhale normally. Mentally scan your body. You might feel tension in your body that you never noticed.
2. Take a slow, deep breath through your nose.
3. Notice your belly and upper body expanding.
4. Exhale in whatever way is most comfortable for you, sighing if you wish.
5. Do this for several minutes, paying attention to the rise and fall of your belly.
6. Choose a word to focus on and vocalize during your exhale. Words like “safe” and “calm” can be effective.
7. Imagine your inhale washing over you like a gentle wave.
8. Imagine your exhale carrying negative and upsetting thoughts and energy away from you.
9. When you get distracted, gently bring your attention back to your breath and your words.

Practice this technique for up to 20 minutes daily when you can.

#WellnessWednesday Focused Breathing
When deep breathing is focused and slow, it can help reduce anxiety. You can do this technique by sitting or lying down in a quiet, comfortable location. Then:
1. Notice how it feels when you inhale and exhale normally. Mentally scan your body. You might feel tension in your body that you never noticed.
2. Take a slow, deep breath through your nose.
3. Notice your belly and upper body expanding.
4. Exhale in whatever way is most comfortable for you, sighing if you wish.
5. Do this for several minutes, paying attention to the rise and fall of your belly.
6. Choose a word to focus on and vocalize during your exhale. Words like “safe” and “calm” can be effective.
7. Imagine your inhale washing over you like a gentle wave.
8. Imagine your exhale carrying negative and upsetting thoughts and energy away from you.
9. When you get distracted, gently bring your attention back to your breath and your words.

Practice this technique for up to 20 minutes daily when you can.

#TalkAboutItTuesday Be aware of how you talk about COVID-19. Your discussion about COVID-19 can increase or decrease your child's fear. If true, remind your child that your family is healthy, and you are going to do everything within your power to keep loved ones safe and well. Carefully listen or have them draw or write out their thoughts and feelings and respond with truth and reassurance.
Via www.cdc.gov

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday
Give the gift of time. Nothing says “I appreciate you” more than investing your time with a loved one. Take a few minutes to spend time with others today. Give them your undivided attention and just be there without your phone, TV, and other distractions and discuss what went well today or this week. Try to make this a regular habit with your family as often as possible.

post_text:
#TalkAboutItTuesday
Let your children's questions guide you.
Answer their questions truthfully, but don't offer unnecessary details or facts. Don't avoid giving them the information that experts indicate as crucial to your children's well-being. Often, children and youth do not talk about their concerns because they are confused or don't want to worry loved ones. Younger children absorb scary information in waves. They ask questions, listen, play, and then repeat the cycle. Children always feel empowered if they can control some aspects of their life. A sense of control reduces fear.
Via Nasponline.org

post_text:
#MindfulMonday - Safari Exercise
The Safari exercise is a great way to help kids learn mindfulness. This activity turns an average, everyday walk into an exciting new adventure.

Tell your kids that you will be going on a safari: their goal is to notice as many birds, bugs, creepy-crawlies, and any other animals as they can. Anything that walks, crawls, swims, or flies is of interest, and they’ll need to focus all of their senses to find them, especially the little ones (Karen Young, 2017).

A similar exercise for adults is the mindfulness walk. This exercise provokes the same response in children that a mindful walk elicits in adults: a state of awareness and grounding in the present.
https://positivepsychology.com/mindfulness-for-children-kids-activities/

POSITIVEPSYCHOLOGY.COM

post_text:
#FamilyFriday Word Association Game

The first person starts by simply saying any word that comes to mind. The next person at the table says whatever word that word makes them think of, and the game goes on. This is a great way to have fun and build vocabulary! Example: Player 1 says the word “blue” and the next person at the table says “water” and the next person says “swimming pool” and the next person says, “summer” and on and on.

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday - Use your words.
Too often we are so busy rushing through our daily activities that we take the small things for granted. Take some time today to be more mindful of your words. Saying things like, “Thank you” and “I appreciate you,” can mean so much when spoken from the heart. Think about how good it feels to hear them! Set a goal for using your words more purposefully today.

Corpus Christi ISD celebrates 80th anniversary of Buc Stadium

With Friday’s opening of the Miller Bucs’ football season, CCISD kicks off a year-long celebration of the 80th anniversary of Buc Stadium and the 60th anniversary of Roy Miller High School and Solomon M. Coles High School winning state titles. Due to the pandemic, seating will be limited at Buc Stadium. The game will be broadcast live TV by KRIS-TV on their KDF station. Following a video tribute at 7:15 p.m., kickoff is set for 7:30 p.m., Friday, Aug. 28.

post_text:
#WellnessWednesday Relaxation Activities: During this time or transition children and adults can experience stress. We will focus on several breathing activities the next few weeks to help us relax our minds.

STUFFED ANIMAL - DEEP BREATHING
Have your child lay down on their back and put a stuffed animal on their belly. Have them breathe in and move the stuffed animal up, then breathe out and bring the stuffed animal back down. This helps teach kids to use their belly to take big deep breaths. A small pillow or other soft object will work just as well.

Via www.copingskillsforkids.com

post_text:
#FamilyFriday Telephone - Here’s a quick fun game that takes no prep time at all.

How to Play: One person starts by whispering a short phrase into the ear of their neighbor to their right. That person then whispers what they heard to the person on their right. And so it continues around the table until it gets to the person to the host’s left. That person then announces what they heard to everyone. If someone didn’t hear what was said in their ear, typically one “redial” is allowed. It’s always fun to hear how the original phrase changed! This is also a great opportunity for children to practice patience, listening and speaking!
text:
#FamilyFriday Telephone - Here’s a quick fun game that takes no prep time at all.

How to Play: One person starts by whispering a short phrase into the ear of their neighbor to their right. That person then whispers what they heard to the person on their right. And so it continues around the table until it gets to the person to the host’s left. That person then announces what they heard to everyone. If someone didn’t hear what was said in their ear, typically one “redial” is allowed. It’s always fun to hear how the original phrase changed! This is also a great opportunity for children to practice patience, listening and speaking!

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday It’s time to revisit (or start) your Family Gratitude Jar
A gratitude jar is a way that you and your children can start each day with a thankful heart. Place a jar/cup in a central location in your house with some scrap pieces of paper and a pen next to it. When you or your children think of something they are grateful for, have them write (or draw) it on a piece of paper and put it in the jar. At a set interval, empty the jar and read all of your thankful thoughts together as a family.

#WellnessWednesday It is vital to our mental health and family dynamics to have a plan for handling stressful moments. Consider having a safe spot to go to in your home to take a moment to calm your mind and slow your breathing.

A “calm” corner creates the perfect space to signal to the family that you need a few moments to relax, breathe and collect your thoughts.

post_text:
#TalkAboutItTuesday
My child is worried about going back to school in person.

How can I help?
Keep an open line of communication about what is worrying your child. It is important to reassure children that we all feel anxious sometimes.

Children may feel nervous or reluctant to return to school, especially if they have been learning at home for months. Discuss some of the changes they may expect at school, such as needing to wear a face covering. Children may also find it difficult being physically distanced from friends and teachers while at school. Encourage them to think about other ways to bond and stay connected.

Reassure children about safety measures in place to keep people healthy. Remind children that they can also help prevent germs spreading by washing their hands with soap and coughing or sneezing into their elbow.

Talk about the positives – seeing people they know at their school and continuing to learn.

via www.unicef.org

UNICEF.ORG

post_text:
#FamilyFriday Story Starters – Tell a story by having one family member start and then proceed around the table adding to it. Each family member gives a sentence to create a full story that could be real or silly.

Example: Parent/Guardian starts with the sentence, “Once upon a time, Cooper the Cat climbed a tree to see what was on the other side of the fence.” The next person at the table adds to it with something like, “When he got to the top of the tree, he saw a giraffe standing on a spaceship.” You can choose to limit the story to one time around the table or just keep going! (Game Courtesy of RaisingArrows.net)

As a result of COVID-19, many families must make decisions about their children's education that factor in student and family safety as well as student learning. This flyer is intended to outline some of the options parents have when returning to school and to share some information regarding those options.

Flyer in English: https://tea.texas.gov/sites/default/files/covid/education_rights_responsibilities_covid.pdf

https://tea.texas.gov/sites/default/files/covid/education-rights-responsibilities-during-covid-spanish.pdf

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday We’ve come a long way since March and the way we function in our world has changed. Our mindset and how we view our current situation can help us to deal with the changes in a positive manner. Let’s revisit the purpose of Thankful Thursdays!

What is Gratitude? Gratitude is linked with many physical, social and emotional benefits. The most effective gratitude activities are ones that engage children’s interests and strengths. Please keep this in mind as you explore thankfulness and gratitude with your children! End the first day of school with discussing one thing that went well today as you celebrate the start of the new school year!

Welcome to our Facebook Q&A session with CCISD RTI Behavior Intervention Specialists! We will be answering your questions in the comments below from 2:00 p.m.-3:00 p.m.

The RTI Behavior Intervention Specialists play an important role in providing support for the social and emotional learning needs of CCISD students.

Topics include: social and emotional tips for transitioning back to school in a virtual learning environment, ideas on how to talk to students of all ages about their feelings concerning going back to school, strategies for families on what they can do to make the transition back to learning easier by providing practical steps caregivers can implement at home and other helpful resources.

Corpus Christi ISD’s curbside service resumes
Starting Thursday, August 13, free breakfast and lunch will be provided to all CCISD students. Curbside service will be offered from 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the district’s 10 middle schools and six comprehensive high schools.

El programa de comidas de Corpus Christi ISD resume
A partir del jueves 13 de agosto, se proporcionará desayuno y almuerzo gratis a todos los estudiantes de CCISD. El servicio se ofrecerá de 10:30 a.m. a 12:30 p.m. en las 10 escuelas intermedias y seis escuelas secundarias integrales del distrito.

post_text:
All schools have specifically defined attendance zones that include residential areas served by each school. On the basis of a student’s home address, CCISD assigns each student to a specific elementary, middle, or high school campus. To determine which school your child should attend, go to the district’s website, www.ccisd.us, and click on School Boundaries to look up specific addresses and determine your attendance zone. For more information on school boundaries and attendance zones, please contact the Office of Assessment and Accountability at 361-844-0396.

Please visit our 2020-2021 CCISD Reopening Plan at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YjE9Yls7o15hl-zMbsLDHBnnK9ZizDDNzOTGPIcMrAM/edit?usp=sharing

post_text: We want to thank everyone who has inquired about computers and hotspots. Thanks to our board of trustees and generous community supporters, we placed several large orders over the course of the spring and summer. Please understand that, due to worldwide demand, some orders are experiencing delays. We are also loaning campus devices whenever possible. We will continue to work with vendors as well as with our families to meet our district’s technology needs. At this time, our priority is issuing one device per household that indicated need. When our inventory of devices allows, we will be glad to loan additional devices. We appreciate your patience during this challenging time, and we give you our commitment that we will work with every student to provide a robust educational experience. Thank you.
text: We want to thank everyone who has inquired about computers and hotspots. Thanks to our board of trustees and generous community supporters, we placed several large orders over the course of the spring and summer. Please understand that, due to worldwide demand, some orders are experiencing delays. We are also loaning campus devices whenever possible. We will continue to work with vendors as well as with our families to meet our district’s technology needs. At this time, our priority is issuing one device per household that indicated need. When our inventory of devices allows, we will be glad to loan additional devices. We appreciate your patience during this challenging time, and we give you our commitment that we will work with every student to provide a robust educational experience. Thank you.

Thank you, everyone, for your patience and suggestions as staff worked on our plan for the new school year. As you review the plan, please understand that this situation remains fluid. As we monitor COVID-19 in our area and receive guidance from local and state officials, our plan may need to change. We appreciate your understanding as we work to create a safe, productive environment for our new school year. We want to assure you that the plan comes with ample support as we move forward together during this challenging time.

As always, we welcome your questions and feedback. Please speak with your supervisor or click the “Contact us” button on the district’s website.

The election for four Board of Trustees positions will be held on Tuesday, November 3. The filing period for Corpus Christi residents interested in running for one of these positions began on Saturday July 18, and continues through 5 p.m. Monday, August 17.

Candidate information is available at ccisd.us, and the filing process may be completed entirely online and submitted at elections@ccisd.us. While Corpus Christi ISD properties remain closed to the public, assistance is available at elections@ccisd.us and 361-695-7427.

post_text: Congratulations! #CCISDproud
shared_text:
Veterans Memorial High School
July 20 at 11:18 AM ·

Congratulations to VMHS students Brooke Morgan, Sriya Chekuri, Christen Adams and Amitra Dongre.

Their Destination Imagination team “the crew” recently competed in the DI global competition and placed 26th in the world! They also received a special award for their project on Thyroid cancer. Below is the feedback from the Appraisers. #EaglePride

“This team displayed tremendous courage by presenting a serious subject without the emotional relief of a happy-ever-after ending. In taking on the issue of thyroid cancer and spreading awareness about the accessibility of thyroid guards, this team showcased their willingness to take risks as well as their artistry in conveying a serious subject in a beautiful way. The Appraisers were moved to tears.”
text:
Congratulations! #CCISDproud

Veterans Memorial High School
July 20 at 11:18 AM ·

Congratulations to VMHS students Brooke Morgan, Sriya Chekuri, Christen Adams and Amitra Dongre.

Their Destination Imagination team “the crew” recently competed in the DI global competition and placed 26th in the world! They also received a special award for their project on Thyroid cancer. Below is the feedback from the Appraisers. #EaglePride

“This team displayed tremendous courage by presenting a serious subject without the emotional relief of a happy-ever-after ending. In taking on the issue of thyroid cancer and spreading awareness about the accessibility of thyroid guards, this team showcased their willingness to take risks as well as their artistry in conveying a serious subject in a beautiful way. The Appraisers were moved to tears.”

post_text:
CCISD to offer remote instruction Aug. 13 through at least Sept. 4

Thank you, everyone, for your patience during this extraordinarily challenging time. Please see the attached announcement that we will provide remote instruction to all CCISD students from Thursday, Aug. 13, through at least Friday, Sept. 4. Classroom instruction is scheduled to resume Tuesday, September 8, with remote instruction continued to be provided to families who prefer it.

We know there are many details yet to share and questions to be answered. Please be assured our staff is working diligently to plan with safety and instructional quality in mind, and we will continue to share information as it becomes available.

Please continue to share your feedback by clicking “Contact us” at ccisd.us. While we may not be able to answer every question individually, we will use your input for our planning and FAQ materials.

Please continue to follow health and safety guidelines to help restore our community to good health. We all want our students and staff to return to the CCISD environment we all love. Thank you!

Classroom instruction is scheduled to resume Tuesday, September 8, with remote instruction continued to be provided to families who prefer it.

We know there are many details yet to share and questions to be answered. Please be assured our staff is working diligently to plan with safety and instructional quality in mind, and we will continue to share information as it becomes available.

Please continue to share your feedback by clicking “Contact us” at ccisd.us. While we may not be able to answer every question individually, we will use your input for our planning and FAQ materials.

Please continue to follow health and safety guidelines to help restore our community to good health. We all want our students and staff to return to the CCISD environment we all love. Thank you!

post_text: Thank you to our staff and families who continue to share questions, suggestions and feedback regarding the 2020-2021 school year. In consultation with local and state authorities, we are continuing to finalize our plan for the new school year. Our goal is to offer a thoughtful, thorough plan for a safe, productive learning environment, be that in-person or online. Staff and student safety are always top priorities, as is the ability to offer substantive lessons. We expect to have more information for you on Thursday afternoon. If you have information to share with us, please click the “Contact us” button on our website, ccisd.us.

shared_text:
Texas Department of State Health Services posted a video to playlist COVID-19: Together for a #HealthyTexas.
July 1 at 3:38 PM ·

This #4thofJuly, share your USA spirit but not coronavirus. Coronavirus can easily spread in family or community gatherings.

Keep gatherings small, stay six feet apart, wash your hands often and wear a face covering around people you don't live with. #HealthyTexas #COVID19TX

Share this post with friends and family to help keep folks safe this Fourth of July.

This video and more Together for a #HealthyTexas videos are available on Texas DSHS YouTube. Share these videos with those closest to you: https://bit.ly/2VysBzW

❤️Together for a #HealthyTexas:
🏡Stay home when possible
😷Wear a face covering in public
↔️Stay 6 feet apart from others
🙌Wash your hands often
🤒If sick, get tested then stay home
🧼Clean your surroundings
🤧Cover coughs and sneezes
👉Don't touch your face

Important and useful #COVID19 info and links:
Open Texas Checklists: open.texas.gov
Testing near you: covidtest.tdem.texas.gov
COVID-19 symptoms: http://bit.ly/2IV3uRh
Caring for someone sick: https://bit.ly/2wf7sS7
All #COVID19TX info: dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus

post_text:
🌞It's officially summer!🌞

In 2020, the June solstice is June 20, at 4:44 P.M. This date marks the official beginning of summer in the Northern Hemisphere, occurring when Earth arrives at the point in its orbit where the North Pole is at its maximum tilt toward the Sun, resulting in the longest day and shortest night of the calendar year.

via Almanac.com

post_text:
Kolda Elementary Librarian, Mrs. Sandy Guzman, provides several reading incentives for students to complete throughout the year. Completion of these reading incentives were a challenge due to COVID, but four students didn’t let social distancing or the lack of access to these books keep them from reaching their goals.

Reese Rocha, Natalie Aguilar, Lyla Longoria and Ethan Muns each completed reading incentives and were able to turn them in through Google Classroom and/or during Kolda’s book drop-off.

“We are very proud of our readers,” stated Mrs. Amanda Wiesen, Kolda Library Assistant. “We are especially proud because three of these readers have completed these reading incentives more than once and our newest Kolda cadet is on his way to a great start.”

post_text:
The district added two locations: Calk-Wilson Elementary School and Cunningham Middle School at South Park. Summer service will be available through July 10. Curbside service will start at 11 a.m. and end at 1 p.m. Meals will be available while supplies last.
- On Mondays, breakfast and lunch will be provided for Monday and Tuesday.
- On Wednesdays, breakfast and lunch will be provided for Wednesday and Thursday.
- On Fridays, breakfast and lunch will be provided for that day.

More info: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Qxpph94FELL5gEJCmHPEXRybXEUVv3jX/view?fbclid=IwAR3kD4CL8BjivSib-O4oxA7GDCHf2zveofUHLhHsGv7mtYRPbVDgivyzVNs

Meals are available to children 18 and younger; children are not required to be CCISD students. In order to comply with federal guidelines, parents without children present must show evidence of a student in the household, such as a student ID or a report card. Once evidence is presented, staff will provide families with a notice to display on the dashboard, eliminating the need to bring evidence daily.

post_text: We share the pain our nation is experiencing as we grieve George Floyd’s death. Diversity is a cornerstone of public education. Education is key to understanding and thriving in our multicultural world. As such, Corpus Christi ISD strives to foster inclusivity and condemns all acts of racism. We stand with the black community, and will continue to model and teach acceptance of, and love for, everyone in our city as well as the wider world.
text: We share the pain our nation is experiencing as we grieve George Floyd’s death. Diversity is a cornerstone of public education. Education is key to understanding and thriving in our multicultural world. As such, Corpus Christi ISD strives to foster inclusivity and condemns all acts of racism. We stand with the black community, and will continue to model and teach acceptance of, and love for, everyone in our city as well as the wider world.

post_text:
Your household may be eligible to receive Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) benefits to buy food. P-EBT is for children 5-18 years old who received SNAP food
benefits for the month of March 2020 and children up to 21 years old who are certified for free or reduced-price meals at school in Texas during the 2019-20 school year. Children
that attend a school that offers free meals to all students (Community Eligibility Provision or Provision 2) are also eligible.

The online application for P-EBT is now open. Please review the criteria to see if you need to apply to receive these benefits. yourtexasbenefits.com/Learn/PEBT

More info:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1QWT7wwpeW4NHl5p_o6iV534YwAT3E6Hk/view

post_text:
What if the June 5 graduation ceremonies are canceled due to bad weather?

In the event the Friday, June 5, graduations are rained out, the ceremonies will be held at 6 p.m. (Collegiate) and 8 p.m. (Branch) on Saturday, June 6. The campuses and the district will continue to monitor the weather, and will announce any changes via official communication channels.

Class of 2020 FAQ page: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Hco_HzfBn4gjXWvhK_kzKNW8SX2oz-yH/view

post_text:
Dear Corpus Christi ISD families and staff:

Corpus Christi ISD is seeking your feedback regarding the district’s response to COVID-19 and distance learning, as well as your feedback on potential school reopening plans for Fall 2020. The district is committed to reopening safely and with all necessary programs and supports for families and staff. Your input is essential in helping us understand how to best serve our community.

The district has partnered with Hanover Research, a private research firm, to conduct a short survey of students (grade 4 and up), parents and staff. This survey is anonymous, and Hanover Research will not share any individual results or identifiable information with the district. The survey takes about 10 minutes and will be available until 5 p.m., Friday, June 5.

Please click the survey link to begin: https://hanover-research.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4SLgPQwmZHot5GJ
shared_text:
HANOVER-RESEARCH.QUALTRICS.COM
Online Survey Software | Qualtrics Survey Solutions

Corpus Christi ISD is seeking your feedback regarding the district’s response to COVID-19 and distance learning, as well as your feedback on potential school reopening plans for Fall 2020. The district has partnered with Hanover Research, a private research firm, to conduct a short survey of students (grade 4 and up), parents and staff. post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD’s curbside service closed May 26-29 to prepare for summer service

After mobilizing to serve approximately 270,000 meals since March 16, Corpus Christi ISD’s Office of Food Services will pause curbside service May 26-29 to prepare for summer service. (The district is closed Monday, May 25, in observance of the Memorial Day holiday.)

Curbside service will resume on Monday, June 1, with service times remaining 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. while supplies last. Summer service will continue the three-days-per-week schedule established in mid-May.

The Office of Food Services is reviewing the list of curbside service locations, and will provide an updated list prior to June 1.

The Office of Food Services is reviewing the list of curbside service locations, and will provide an updated list prior to June 1.

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday 4 Parts of Gratitude
Research in the Raising Grateful Children Project at UNC Chapel Hill revealed that gratitude has four parts:
➡️Noticing – Recognizing the things you have to be grateful for.
➡️Thinking – Thinking about why you’ve been given those things.
➡️Feeling – The emotions you experience as a result of the things you’ve been given.
➡️Doing – The way you express appreciation.

How can you practice the four parts of gratitude as a family?

➡️Feeling – The emotions you experience as a result of the things you’ve been given.
➡️Doing – The way you express appreciation.

How can you practice the four parts of gratitude as a family?

post_text: #WellnessWednesday Yoga Pose: Yoga is a great way for children to relax. Today, try the child’s pose: Have your child kneel down with his backside resting on his ankles. post_text:
#TalkAboutItTuesday Interpret their emotions

Once children can notice and name their emotions, it is time to explore the reasons why they might be feeling a certain way. Interpreting emotions means understanding how emotions can help us. For example, anger can help us fight against problems or sadness may allow us to connect with those we love. It is important to communicate that all feelings are helpful, even the ones that cause us to be uncomfortable! In order for students to manage their emotions in positive ways, they need to have words to describe them.

Emotional literacy is the ability to notice, accurately name and interpret our emotions. You can help children develop this key SEL skill by helping them notice feelings in the body, increasing their emotion vocabulary and ability to interpret emotions.(Edutopia)

post_text:
Why are ceremonies being held at Cabaniss Stadium?

Cabaniss Sports Complex offers multiple entrances and exits to the complex as well as to Cabaniss Field. The Cabaniss location also includes ample parking, and there is no road construction in the area. While we love and honor the traditions at Buc Stadium, holding graduations at Cabaniss is helping CCISD offer live celebrations while being mindful of health officials’ guidelines.

More info: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Hco_HzfBn4gjXWvhK_kzKNW8SX2oz-yH/view

post_text:
🎓What is the status of the May graduation ceremonies at American Bank Center?🎓

At this time, the state of Texas is not allowing indoor ceremonies. Starting May 29, the state of Texas will allow graduations to be held in outdoor settings, as long as safety precautions are observed. CCISD continues to study the options for celebrating our seniors. If it is safe to hold an outdoor celebration, options may include holding evening graduation ceremonies in June at a CCISD stadium. We also have tentative reservations for late July at the American Bank Center. We appreciate everyone’s patience as we plan a safe celebration for our students, and we will update everyone as soon as a decision is reached.

🎓What is the status of the May graduation ceremonies at American Bank Center?🎓

CCISD continues to study the options for celebrating our seniors. If it is safe to hold an outdoor celebration, options may include holding evening graduation ceremonies in June at a CCISD stadium. We also have tentative reservations for late July at the American Bank Center. We appreciate everyone’s patience as we plan a safe celebration for our students, and we will update everyone as soon as a decision is reached.

#WellnessWednesady Stress Balls:
Make your own stress ball by filling balloons with dry lentils or rice.Take the ball in one or both hands and squeeze and release. Experiment with squeezing the ball. Find a way that is right for you, adjusting the speed, pressure, and timing of your squeezes to whatever way you like. This helps relieve muscle tension and stress.

post_text:
In light of the Texas Education Agency’s May 5 guidance on graduations, what is CCISD’s plan?

We continue to explore options for a safe, meaningful celebration of our seniors. This may be a virtual ceremony, a hybrid (in-person and virtual) ceremony, a drive-through ceremony, or – as some districts in Texas are planning – a stadium graduation that would include controlled attendance and safety measures. We know our seniors are anxious to have firm plans to look forward to, and we will share updates as soon as possible.

post_text:
Today, we celebrate the 8th Annual School Lunch Hero Day! Thank you to the Food Services central office staff, kitchen staff, warehouse staff and truck drivers. Each and every one of them have been working diligently and differently to be sure that the children of the Corpus Christi community can be served meals. We are #CCISDproud of you!

Between preparing healthy meals for our students, adhering to strict nutrition standards, navigating student food allergies, and offering service with a smile, our Food Services department are true heroes.

post_text:
As Texas begins a gradual reopening on May 1, Corpus Christi ISD properties will continue to follow state guidelines for school districts and remain closed to the public. We may be reached online and by phone. Please see our current status, below. Stay safe, everyone!

Campuses
All CCISD school buildings remain closed to the public. Our distance learning continues. Students, please continue your schoolwork and stay in touch with your teacher and your school. All campuses may be reached via phone and email.

CCISD employees
The district’s important work continues. Please continue to follow the schedule determined by your supervisor, and keep informed by staying in touch with your supervisor.

CCISD Administration building
The Administration building remains closed to the public. If you need assistance and have not been able to reach the department you need, please email communications@ccisd.us.

Metro School of Design (Metro Prep, 1 Battlin Buc Blvd) serves students in 7th through 12th grade within Roy Miller High School. Metro Prep is a school-within-a-school concept.

post_text:
#TalkAboutItTuesday Helping Kids Conquer Worry

To help your kids manage what's worrying them, find out what's on their minds.
- Be available and take an interest in what's happening.
- Take casual opportunities to ask how it's going. As you listen to stories of the day's events, be sure to ask about what your kids think and feel about what happened.
- If your child seems to be worried about something, ask about it.
- Encourage kids to put what's bothering them into words.
- Ask for key details and listen. Sometimes just sharing the story with you can help lighten their load.

post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD’s curbside service schedule adjusted to maximize safety
As Corpus Christi ISD works to maximize employee safety while continuing to provide meals to area children, curbside service at the district’s 17 school sites will change from daily service to three times weekly: Monday, Wednesday and Friday. The change is effective beginning Monday, April 27.

Curbside service will start at 11 a.m. and end at 1 p.m. Meals will be available while supplies last.
- On Mondays, breakfast and lunch will be provided for Monday and Tuesday. Monday’s lunch
will include a heated main dish.
-On Wednesdays, breakfast and lunch will be provided for Wednesday and Thursday.
Wednesday’s lunch will include a heated main dish.
- On Friday, breakfast and lunch will be provided for that day.

Meals are available to children 18 and younger; children are not required to be CCISD students.

Del Mar College is at Del Mar College.
April 21 at 10:19 AM · Corpus Christi, TX ·

Students from kindergarten to college can now access Wi-Fi at four Del Mar College parking lots seven-days-a-week between 8 a.m. and 7 p.m. Current students can login using their DMC email and password. Non-DMC students can login as a guest and fill out an access account request.

🗺 East Campus Venters Business Bldg.
🗺 West Campus Health Sciences Bldg.
🗺 Center for Economic Development 3209 S. Staples
🗺 Northwest Center 13725 Northwest Blvd.

ℹ https://delmar.edu/offices/cro/cv/public-wifi.html

post_text:
#TalkAboutItTuesday Childhood Stress
As providers and caretakers, adults tend to view the world of children as happy and carefree. After all, kids don't have jobs to keep or bills to pay, so what could they possibly have to worry about?

Plenty! Even very young children have worries and feel stress to some degree. Learn more: https://kidshealth.org/en/parents/stress.html?WT.ac=ctg#catfeelings

We are aware of Gov. Abbott's Executive Order closing all schools for the remainder of the school year. We will be working with the TEA on next steps, and will keep staff and families informed. While our buildings will remain closed, distance learning will continue.

Gov. Abbott indicated districts will receive guidance in the coming days regarding graduation ceremonies. Seniors, we continue to be so proud of you, and we know your future is bright, even during these challenging times.

post_text: #ThankfulThursday Make a Family Gratitude Jar: A gratitude jar is a way that your and your children can start each day with a thankful heart. Place a jar/cup in a central location in your house with some scrap pieces of paper and a pen next to it. When your or your children think of something they are grateful for, have them write it on a piece of paper and put it in the jar. At a set interval, empty the jar and read all of your thankful thoughts together as a family.
text: #ThankfulThursday Make a Family Gratitude Jar: A gratitude jar is a way that your and your children can start each day with a thankful heart. Place a jar/cup in a central location in your house with some scrap pieces of paper and a pen next to it. When your or your children think of something they are grateful for, have them write it on a piece of paper and put it in the jar. At a set interval, empty the jar and read all of your thankful thoughts together as a family.

If, due to safety concerns related to COVID-19, CCISD cannot hold spring graduations as originally planned, the district continues to work on tentative rescheduling dates. Please see below the updated, tentative schedule for CCISD’s six comprehensive high schools. These dates are subject to change. CCISD will provide information regarding plans for other campuses as it becomes available.

We understand some students may not be available to attend a delayed graduation, and will ensure graduates receive their diplomas and final transcripts in a timely manner. Thank you for your continued patience.

post_text:
As we continue to help our community stay safe, the Monday, April 13, school board meeting will be held via videoconference. The meeting is scheduled to begin at 3:30 p.m. Members of the public and the media may view the meeting by clicking on this link: https://www.ccisd.us/SUPERINTENDENT-BOARD-Board-Meetings.

Public comment may be submitted using this form: https://forms.ccisd.us/Forms/xbQhM. Comments will be accepted until 1:30 p.m. on Monday, April 13. Comments that do not pertain to items on the agenda will be read aloud to the Board, but the Board will not respond to those comments or questions during the meeting. Thank you!

post_text:
#MindfulMonday The S.T.O.P Practice: Creating Space Around Automatic Reactions.

This “portable” mindfulness practice can support you as difficult moments arise at any point in your day. The four steps of the STOP practice can take as little as a few seconds to a few minutes to complete. Try it out and see how long you prefer doing each step.

https://www.mindful.org/the-s-t-o-p-practice-creating-space-around-automatic-reactions/

post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD calling!📞
We have about 1,500 students we haven’t been able to reach since our schools closed. Students and families, we miss you! We are here to talk with you about this difficult time, to help in any way we can, and to help you continue your education. Please contact your principal or teacher as soon as possible. If you need assistance doing so, please email communications@ccisd.us. Talk to you soon! #CCISDfamily

¡Corpus Christi ISD llamando!!📞
Tenemos alrededor de 1,500 estudiantes que no hemos podido alcanzar desde que cerraron nuestras escuelas. Estudiantes y familias, ¡los extrañamos! Estamos aquí para hablar con ustedes sobre este momento difícil, para ayudarlos en todo lo que podamos y para ayudarlos a continuar su educación. Comuníquese con su director o maestro lo antes posible. Si necesita ayuda para hacerlo, envíe un correo electrónico a communications@ccisd.us. ¡Hablamos pronto! #CCISDfamily

post_text:
Good Afternoon. We are having technical difficulties with the live stream. We will provide updates here on Facebook. We apologize for the inconvenience.

Updates:

Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez opened with a district update, including the expansion of the curbside meals to include breakfast and lunch as well as now offering meals at 17 campuses, from 10:30am-1pm weekdays.

Executive Director of Technology Sean Babcock is giving the board an update on district WiFi and technology upgrades. We will post this report later today. Upgrades include new equipment as well as improved WiFi. Bond 2018 funded an additional 5 ChromeBooks to each classroom.

post_text: Good Morning, CCISD family. We know everyone is weary, worried and washing their hands. We hope you find some rest this weekend. Meanwhile, we will continue sharing information with you. We are answering questions emailed to communications@ccisd.us, and we are placing the answers in the FAQ on our website. We will post a FAQ for employees by the end of the day today. As we end the week, we thank you for your patience as we all work to help keep our community healthy.

We are answering questions emailed to communications@ccisd.us, and we are placing the answers in the FAQ on our website. We will post a FAQ for employees by the end of the day today. March 16 at 11:29 AM ·

In response to the rapidly evolving situation around the coronavirus (COVID-19), the College Board is canceling the May 2, 2020, SAT administration. Makeup exams for the March 14 administration (scheduled March 28) are also canceled. Registered students will receive refunds.

The College Board will provide future additional SAT testing opportunities for students as soon as feasible in place of canceled administrations.

During this challenging time, our focus will remain on the health and safety of students. We will be flexible, thoughtful, and collaborative in exploring ways to continue to support student learning and provide opportunities to test.

More details: http://spr.ly/61861subu.

post_text:
A message from Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez:

Good Evening, CCISD staff and families.

I want to remind everyone that our schools and district offices will remain closed through Friday, March 20. While I know this is an inconvenience, we believe it is important for us to do our part to keep our area at low risk for the novel coronavirus. I encourage everyone to continue to follow guidance from health officials.

Staff members: unless you are instructed otherwise by your supervisor, there is no need to report to work until Monday, March 23, although I ask you to monitor your email and/or phone.

Curbside lunch service for students 18 and younger will be offered from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. each weekday at six of our high schools. For details about this and other updates during our closure, please visit ccisd.us.

I know this is a challenging, worrisome time for many of us. I appreciate your continued support of our students and staff. We will continue to keep you informed, and we are looking forward to seeing everyone on Monday, March 23.

post_text: We hope all of CCISD students and staff are enjoying their Spring Break!
text: We hope all of CCISD students and staff are enjoying their Spring Break!

post_text:
Good Morning, everyone.

We wanted to let you know that we are aware that local health department officials have informed some residents individually that they may have come into contact in the community with someone who may have been exposed to the novel coronavirus. We want to reassure you that there are no confirmed cases of the virus in our area.

We continue to encourage staff and students to practice healthy habits, including thorough hand-washing and staying home when ill.

Anyone who believes they may have the novel coronavirus should call the local health district at (361) 826-7200 for guidance.

We hope everyone is enjoying a safe, healthy Spring Break. We are looking forward to seeing students and staff on Monday, March 16.
Thank you!

post_text:
CCISD names athletic coordinator/head football coach for Richard King School.

🎉 Douglas Foster has been named to lead Richard King High School's athletics program. Foster currently serves as assistant head coach and special teams coordinator at Foster High School in Lamar ISD. "Coach Foster joins CCISD with a wealth of experience as well as familiarity with the Coastal Bend," Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said. "We look forward to seeing our Mustang athletics program thrive under his leadership."

Foster will begin working in his new capacity at the end of March.

As always, we encourage our students and staff to practice healthy habits, including frequent, thorough hand-washing. Thank you for helping us keep our school communities healthy!

This morning, we celebrated Granny Davis's 100th birthday at Rafael Galvan Elementary School. Granny Davis volunteers in Mrs. Garcia Pre-K class. During the celebration, the Galvan Elementary School Choir sang Happy Birthday to Granny Davis, she was gifted 100 carnations in honor of her 100th birthday and students presented her with birthday cards. Granny Davis has been with CCISD over 25 years! #CCISDproud

post_text:
King High School football coach to step down and pursue administrator role

After 11 years of service to Corpus Christi ISD, King High School Athletic Coordinator and Head Football Coach Albert “Eddie” Hesseltine is leaving the district to become an administrator at Sinton Independent School District.

Hesseltine expects to complete his tenure at CCISD in early February.
text:
King High School football coach to step down and pursue administrator role

After 11 years of service to Corpus Christi ISD, King High School Athletic Coordinator and Head Football Coach Albert “Eddie” Hesseltine is leaving the district to become an administrator at Sinton Independent School District.

Hesseltine expects to complete his tenure at CCISD in early February.

post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD names three to district-level positions

The district has promoted three experienced employees to fill key positions. Click on each picture for more information.

🎉Jennifer Arismendi will serve as Executive Director for Educational Support, following the retirement of Dr. Ada Besinaiz.

🎉Debora Meador has been named Director of Food Services, following the retirement of longtime director Jody Houston in December.

🎉Kimberly Story has been named Director of Advanced Academics.

post_text:
Mary Carroll High School’s tiger gets new look in preparation for new campus

Mary Carroll High School’s tiger has some fresh stripes. As the school prepares for a new campus, their mascot, the tiger, has a new look.

Students, their families and school staff at Carroll High School cast ballots November 11 through November 15 to select a new design.

The new campus is scheduled to welcome students for the 2022-2023 school year. #CCISDproud

post_text: Check out Texas Department of Public Safety's free iWatchTexas app!
shared_text:
Texas Department of Public Safety
September 13, 2019 at 2:00 PM ·

With the (FREE) iWatchTexas mobile app, you can help law enforcement combat potential criminal, terroristic or school safety threats. If you see something suspicious, you are urged to report it through the state’s iWatchTexas system. Reports can be made through the mobile app, online at iwatchtx.org or by calling 844-643-2251.

The iWatchTexas program was created as a partnership between communities and law enforcement, and utilizes citizen-sourced tips related to criminal activity. The app is available for both iPhone and Android users. Please note: iWatchTexas is not designed to report emergencies. If a situation requires an emergency response, call 911.

post_text:
REMINDER:
➡️CCISD Clear Bag Policy⬅️
As part of its work to continually improve district safety and security for students, staff and visitors, CCISD is implementing a clear-bag requirement for all athletic events at Cabaniss Sports Complex and Buccaneer Stadium, starting the 2019-2020 school year.

Any visitor, spectator or patron attending an event held at these venues will be required to follow this procedure for high school and middle school events.

Clear tote bags may be plastic, vinyl or pvc. They may not exceed 12 inches by 12 inches by 6 inches. A small clutch bag no larger than 4.5 inches by 6.5 inches─ approximately the size of a hand─ (with or without a handle or strap) is approved. Other bags such as backpacks, diaper bags and camera bags, etc. will not be allowed in the stadium.

H-E-B will offer these bags during their Back to School season. Mira’s Sports and More will offer the bags at their retail store.

Any visitor, spectator or patron attending an event held at these venues will be required to follow this procedure for high school and middle school events.

Clear tote bags may be plastic, vinyl or pvc. They may not exceed 12 inches by 12 inches by 6 inches. A small clutch bag no larger than 4.5 inches by 6.5 inches─ approximately the size of a hand─ (with or without a handle or strap) is approved. Other bags such as backpacks, diaper bags and camera bags, etc. will not be allowed in the stadium.

post_text:
Please help us congratulate Jessica Albert, who has been named principal of the district’s Student Support Center.

Ms. Albert has served in CCISD since 2007. She most recently served as an Assistant Principal at Solomon M. Coles High School & Education Center, where she has worked since 2015.

Prior to her role at Coles, she served as a math teacher and, later, as a part-time assistant principal at Cullen Place Middle School. Ms. Albert earned a bachelor’s and a master’s in accounting, both from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, and her principal and superintendent certificates from Lamar University.

This completes our principal assignments for the 2019-2020 school year. We hope everyone has a wonderful first day of school!

post_text: As you may notice, we are beginning to roll out the new design of our district and campus websites. In addition to ensuring users of all abilities may access information, we took the opportunity to modernize the site. An important consideration is that many of us now view sites on our phones or iPads, which is a different viewing experience from a desktop. The site has more contemporary look while continuing to promote campus and district spirit.

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Scott Walker, principal of Veterans Memorial High School!

Walker, who served as an assistant principal at Veterans Memorial High School for three years, will become the second principal in the school’s history.

He holds a bachelor’s degree in history from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi and a master’s degree in educational leadership from Lamar University. In 2011, he was Richard King High School’s Teacher of the Year.

“The committee saw Mr. Walker as a leader who could not only guide Veterans Memorial through a seamless transition but also bring a fresh vision to this already highly accomplished campus,” Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said. “We know the Eagles community will welcome him in this role.”
text:
Please join us in congratulating Scott Walker, principal of Veterans Memorial High School!

Walker, who served as an assistant principal at Veterans Memorial High School for three years, will become the second principal in the school’s history.

He holds a bachelor’s degree in history from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi and a master’s degree in educational leadership from Lamar University. In 2011, he was Richard King High School’s Teacher of the Year.

“The committee saw Mr. Walker as a leader who could not only guide Veterans Memorial through a seamless transition but also bring a fresh vision to this already highly accomplished campus,” Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said. “We know the Eagles community will welcome him in this role.”

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Carolyn Bence, principal of Mireles Elementary School!

Bence, an assistant principal at Lorenzo de Zavala Elementary School since 2017, has been promoted to principal of E.E. & Jovita Mireles Elementary School.

She holds a bachelor of arts from Emory University, two master’s degrees from the University of Texas at Austin and has worked in CCISD since 2009.

“Ms. Bence is a trusted leader throughout our district, and we know the Mireles staff and families will welcome her as their principal,” Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said.

Please join us in congratulating Carolyn Bence, principal of Mireles Elementary School!

She holds a bachelor of arts from Emory University, two master’s degrees from the University of Texas at Austin and has worked in CCISD since 2009.

“Ms. Bence is a trusted leader throughout our district, and we know the Mireles staff and families will welcome her as their principal,” Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said.

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Alexis Soulas, principal of Kaffie Middle School!

Soulas, who was principal of E.E. & Jovita Mireles Elementary School for three years, has been named principal of Harold C. Kaffie Middle School.

Soulas holds a bachelor’s in education from Texas A&I University, as well as a master’s in counseling and a mid-management certificate, both from Texas A&M University-Kingsville. She has served in CCISD for 10 years, including assistant principal assignments at Marvin Baker Middle School and Cullen Place Middle School.

“Ms. Soulas has been an exemplary leader at Mireles, and we know she will provide the same level of service at Kaffie,” Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez said. “We are excited to have her experience and vision at the middle school level.”

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Enrique Vela, Moody High School’s new principal!

Vela, who served as an assistant principal at Foy H. Moody High School for eight years, will return to the campus as principal. During the 2018-2019 school year, he served as principal of CCISD’s Student Support Center.

Vela, a graduate of Roy Miller High School, holds a bachelor’s and a master’s degree from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, as well as a graduate certificate in superintendent studies.

“Mr. Vela’s extensive, positive experience at Moody made him the committee’s clear choice to serve as the campus’ next leader,” said Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. ”We know he will take this strong campus to new heights.”

“Mr. Vela’s extensive, positive experience at Moody made him the committee’s clear choice to serve as the campus’ next leader,” said Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. ”We know he will take this strong campus to new heights.”

post_text:
TEA releases district scores: Corpus Christi ISD now a “B” district

After another year of focused work on improving student outcomes districtwide, CCISD is pleased to have earned an 86, or “B,” from the Texas Education Agency’s state accountability system.

Collegiate High School and Harold T. Branch Academy for Career and Technical Education earned “A” ratings for the second year. Veterans Memorial High School progressed to an “A,” for a total of three “A” ratings for district high schools. Roy Miller High School remained at a “B,” while the remaining high school campuses progressed from “C” to “B” ratings.

Additional “A” campuses in the district include the Early Childhood Development Center, Zachary Kolda Elementary School, E.E. & Jovita Mireles Elementary School, Weldon Smith Elementary School, and Windsor Park Elementary School.

post_text:
CCISD has named Laura Perales principal of Oak Park Elementary School.

Perales has been in education for 23 years, 21 of those years here at CCISD. She most recently served as an Assessment and Accountability Advisor for the Office of Assessment and Accountability where she would oversee and coordinate all state assessments at Roy Miller High School along with its vertical learning community.

She has previously served in roles such as elementary assistant principal at Oak Park Elementary School, TTIPS instructional coach, instructional teacher advisor and elementary math coach. She received her Bachelors in Interdisciplinary Studies and her Masters in Curriculum and Instruction from Texas A&M University – Corpus Christi.

post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD names Chief of Staff

Corpus Christi ISD has named Kimberley Donaldson James as the district’s Chief of Staff. She will begin transitioning to her new role on Monday, July 29.

James previously served as the founding principal of Veterans Memorial High School, which opened in 2015. Her 21 years in administration include serving at elementary, middle and high schools, including seven years as principal of Rockport-Fulton High School.

CCISD will fill additional leadership positions during the summer months. The 2019-2020 school year begins Monday, August 26.
text:
Corpus Christi ISD names Chief of Staff

Corpus Christi ISD has named Kimberley Donaldson James as the district’s Chief of Staff. She will begin transitioning to her new role on Monday, July 29.

James previously served as the founding principal of Veterans Memorial High School, which opened in 2015. Her 21 years in administration include serving at elementary, middle and high schools, including seven years as principal of Rockport-Fulton High School.

CCISD will fill additional leadership positions during the summer months. The 2019-2020 school year begins Monday, August 26.

post_text:
Corpus Christi ISD names Executive Director of School Leadership

Corpus Christi ISD has named Dr. Sandra Clement as Executive Director of School Leadership. She will join the district’s school leadership team and begin the transition to her new role on Monday, July 29.

Clement previously served as principal of Foy H. Moody High School for seven years, and has worked in CCISD for 15 years.

CCISD will fill additional leadership positions during the summer months. The 2019-2020 school year begins Monday, August 26.

post_text:
CCISD is pleased to offer online registration for all new and returning students. Online registration is required for all students who are returning to school in CCISD.

You will receive an email from our online registration provider PowerSchool with a subject line - Corpus Christi Independent School District Returning Student Registration for your student’s name. This email will arrive on, or before, Monday, July 22. You will receive a unique email for each returning student. This message will contain a link and personalized code for access to that students registration form. The message will also include detailed information for creating an online registration account (if you do not have one already) and completing the registration form successfully. Please keep in mind that this account is separate from your Home Access Center account. If you have any difficulty or are unable to find the email, please contact the Student Support Services office at 695-7242

post_text:
CCISD names new Mary Carroll High School principal
Dr. Jamie Copeland, who has held leadership positions in CCISD for nine years, including serving as an assistant principal at Mary Carroll High School from 2010 to 2014, has been chosen to lead the campus.

She previously served as principal of Harold C. Kaffie Middle School. Prior to leading Kaffie, she was the principal of Joseph T. Dawson Elementary School. Copeland is a graduate of the University of the Incarnate Word and Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi.

“Dr. Copeland is a proven leader in our district,” said CCISD Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. “Her experience on the Carroll campus, as well as in the schools that feed to Carroll High School, made her the ideal choice to lead the Tigers as they look forward to moving to a new building in the coming years.”

Kaffie and Carroll staff learned of the appointment Thursday morning.
text:
CCISD names new Mary Carroll High School principal
Dr. Jamie Copeland, who has held leadership positions in CCISD for nine years, including serving as an assistant principal at Mary Carroll High School from 2010 to 2014, has been chosen to lead the campus.

She previously served as principal of Harold C. Kaffie Middle School. Prior to leading Kaffie, she was the principal of Joseph T. Dawson Elementary School. Copeland is a graduate of the University of the Incarnate Word and Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi.

“Dr. Copeland is a proven leader in our district,” said CCISD Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. “Her experience on the Carroll campus, as well as in the schools that feed to Carroll High School, made her the ideal choice to lead the Tigers as they look forward to moving to a new building in the coming years.”

Kaffie and Carroll staff learned of the appointment Thursday morning.

post_text:
CCISD to bid farewell to Carroll High School principal
CCISD is preparing to say farewell to Mary Carroll High School Principal Dr. Kelly Manlove, who will be leaving the district to take a position in the private sector.

Manlove will complete her contract with the district. The district will conduct interviews for a new principal, and expects to complete the process during the summer months.

Manlove served CCISD for 11 years, including six as Carroll’s leader.

“Dr. Manlove has played an important role in fostering a sense of community and pride throughout the Carroll campus,” said CCISD Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. “We join the Tiger family in wishing her the best.”

Carroll staff learned of Manlove’s decision Tuesday afternoon. We wish her the best!
text:
CCISD to bid farewell to Carroll High School principal
CCISD is preparing to say farewell to Mary Carroll High School Principal Dr. Kelly Manlove, who will be leaving the district to take a position in the private sector.

Manlove will complete her contract with the district. The district will conduct interviews for a new principal, and expects to complete the process during the summer months.

Manlove served CCISD for 11 years, including six as Carroll’s leader.

“Dr. Manlove has played an important role in fostering a sense of community and pride throughout the Carroll campus,” said CCISD Superintendent Dr. Roland Hernandez. “We join the Tiger family in wishing her the best.”

Carroll staff learned of Manlove’s decision Tuesday afternoon. We wish her the best!

post_text:
As we enter the final days of the school year, we want to remind everyone that all threats, including those meant as pranks, are taken seriously and have serious consequences. Campus administrators and the CCISD Police Department increase monitoring at the end of every school year as a precaution.

Anyone with information about threats or pranks is encouraged to contact the police or campus administrators. Together, we can keep our schools safe and celebrate our students’ many accomplishments!

post_text: Thanks to swift action and collaborative effort by CCPD and CCISD PD, the situation that led to an hour-long lockdown this morning at VMHS has been resolved. An arrest has been made in connection with a social media post that contained a threat. CCISD takes all threats seriously, including ones made on social media. Students are safe and coursework continued during the lockdown.
